titleStmt.title: T-S K6.38

msContents.summary: Piyyuṭim by Samuel the Third, pertaining to Parašaṯ Pequde (Leviticus 38:21-40:38). The bifolia are contiguous, and the material is arranged as follows (page references and line numbers refer to Yahalom and Katsumata, 2014): P2, f. 1r: material from the yoṣer (p. 422, line 47ff.); P2, f. 1v: yoṣer, continued (p. 423, line 58ff.); P1, f. 2r: yoṣer, continued (p. 424, line 70ff.); P1, f. 2v: final two lines of the yoṣer (p.425), followed by the first 13 lines of the ofan (p. 426); P3, f. 1r: the remainder of the ofan (p. 426, line 14ff.) followed by the meʾorot and most of the ahava (p. 427); P3, f. 1v: The final line of the ahava, followed by the first part of the zulat (p. 427f.); P3, f. 2r: zulat continued (p. 428, line 8ff.); P3, f. 2v: conclusion of the zulat, and first line of the מי כמוך (p. 429f.); P1, f. 1r: most of the מי כמוך, followed by most of the י׳ מלכנו (p. 430f.); P1, f. 1v: conclusion of the י׳ מלכנו (p. 431), followed by a note indicating that Beraḵot b. Yefet wrote the foregoing material. The remainder of P1 f. 1v contains the beginning of a זולת לארוס, which continues on P2 f. 2r-v.

msItem.title: Piyyuṭ
msItem.note: In T-S 13J1.21 the same Beraḵot b. Yefet (as can be seen from the identical signature) is signatory to a legal document dated 1150 CE. T-S 18J1.25 (a legal document dated 1143 CE) apparently holds the signature of the same person (though on this occasion Beraḵot is written defectively rather than plene). One Abū Saʿīd Beraḵot the cantor b. Yefet is mentioned in a legal document dated 1178 CE, though it is not clear if this refers to the same figure as the aforementioned Beraḵot b. Yefet. The text of the זולת לארוס (P1 f. 1v; P2 f. 2r-v) is written in a larger, far less accomplished hand than that of Beraḵot b. Yefet.

history.provenance: Donated by Dr Solomon Schechter and his patron Dr Charles Taylor in 1898 as part of the Taylor-Schechter Genizah Collection

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
